thread.title_full: ANZ had 3% of workforce breach code of conduct in 2014 | afr.com

author: Sarah Danckert
title: ANZ had 3% of workforce breach code of conduct in 2014
text:
ANZ financed a sugar plantation in Cambodia that allegedly used child labour. Share on twitter by Sarah Danckert ANZ has revealed more than 1700 of its staff breached the company's code of conduct in the last financial year as it argues penalties for overseas corruption should be softened.
ANZ has aggressively targeted expansion into Asia and some sources suggested this had let to conduct issues in countries including Malaysia and Cambodia. The bank has also stood down several traders in the wake of an ongoing investigation into the manipulation of the bank bill swap rate .
ANZ revealed the breaches voluntarily in its submission to the senate Economics References Committee Inquiry into Foreign Bribery.
As a result of the breaches more than 550 staff had left the bank. ANZ dismissed 336 staff members, while a further 229 employees resigned.
The bank also issued 739 formal warnings for breach of ANZ's code of conduct, while 414 staff members were given verbal warnings.
"Breaches ranged from conflict of interest through to allegations of fraud, bullying and email misuse," ANZ said in its submission to the inquiry.
According to ANZ's website its "headcount" for the year to September 2014 was 50,824. A spokesman said this only related to full time staff and including part time staff the number in 2015 was 65,000. He declined to provide the equivalent number for 2014.
Eliminating corruption 'desirable' ANZ operates in 30 countries around the world. As part of its push into Asia, the bank has set up units in Indonesia, Laos, Myanmar, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam.
It also has an extensive network of offices in the South Pacific including corruption hotspots Papua New Guinea and Timor Leste.
"ANZ firmly believes that eliminating bribery and corruption from international business transactions is a desirable goal," the bank said in its submission.
Senator Sam Dastyari, who chairs the senate economics committee hearing the foreign bribery inquiry congratulated ANZ on the disclosure in its submission.
"These figures highlight the enormity of the challenges Australian companies face overseas even when they are trying to do the right thing," he said.
"The need for legislative reform is not only about catching out bad operators it's about making sure that companies who are trying do the right thing are able to do it in an easier way with clearer rules."
This year it emerged the bank had suspended seven traders as a result of an investigation by the Australian Securities and Investment Commission into rigging of bank bill swap rates .
A spokesman for ANZ said "the data doesn't include any staff involved in the BBSW issue as it covers the period to 30 September 2014".
Responding to inquiries from Fairfax Media, the ANZ spokesman said: "We have only three staff members working in our Representative Office in Malaysia. Although we have a minority interest in Ambank, all Ambank staff are Ambank employees."
The bank's 24 per cent owned associate AmBank is embroiled in one of the largest corruption scandals in Malaysia's history.
It is alleged 2.67 billion ringgit ($847 million) intended for the government-sponsored 1 Malaysia Development found its way into the personal bank accounts of Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, allegedly including his AmBank account.
ANZ's exposure to "possible corruption issues in Malaysia" was recently cited as a challenge the bank was facing by CLSA banking analysts.
Meanwhile in Cambodia, ANZ financed a sugar project that allegedly involved child labour, forced evictions and government land acquisitions through its ANZ Royal Bank subsidiary.
There has been speculation ANZ will look to sever its ties with its Cambodian banking arm following the sugar scandal. The bank declined to clarify whether staff from its Cambodian venture had breached its code of conduct during the 2014 financial year.
ANZ said it would also support a self-reporting regime that includes softer penalties for corruption and bribery including "negotiated settlements, non-prosecution agreements and deferred prosecution agreements".
"The current legislative framework does not give companies sufficient certainty as to when and what information or concerns should be raised with law enforcement and what are the consequences of that disclosure," the bank said.
